body_html:
This is using the v0.10 release and not compiled from scratch at the head. Here is a script I built for a quick benchmark around just computing the moments (very non-rigorous, but hopefully helpful):

import tensorflow as tf
import datetime

a = tf.ones([64, 256, 256, 32])
mean, variance = tf.nn.moments(a, [0, 1, 2])

with tf.Session() as sess:
    start = datetime.datetime.now()
    result = sess.run([mean, variance])
    end = datetime.datetime.now()

print(end - start)

Output on CPU: 0:00:01.318907
Output on GPU: 0:00:00.651986

This is basically BN after my first convolution; perhaps these times are actually reasonable? It is a fairly large matrix.

body:
This is using the v0.10 release and not compiled from scratch at the head. Here is a script I built for a quick benchmark around just computing the moments (very non-rigorous, but hopefully helpful):

```
import tensorflow as tf
import datetime

a = tf.ones([64, 256, 256, 32])
mean, variance = tf.nn.moments(a, [0, 1, 2])

with tf.Session() as sess:
    start = datetime.datetime.now()
    result = sess.run([mean, variance])
    end = datetime.datetime.now()

print(end - start)
```

Output on CPU: 0:00:01.318907
Output on GPU: 0:00:00.651986

This is basically BN after my first convolution; perhaps these times are actually reasonable? It is a fairly large matrix.
